Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Interactive Dynamics of Wildlife Populations, Human Health and Household Wealth in Rural Africa
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project integrates ecology, economics, sociology and public health to illuminate and predict a) how human health and household wealth separately and interactively affect human reliance on biodiversity, and b) how harvested biodiversity impacts household wealth and human health. Data collection occurs at the level of individuals and households at nine rural sites in Ghana, Kenya and Madagascar where, like many regions of the world, communities are economically marginalized and the sustainable use of natural resources is essential to livelihoods, health and survival. The systems-based model developed through this integration across disciplines will provide a framework to compare the relative importance of ecological, socioeconomic or health factors for the sustainability of ecosystems and societies. Furthermore, by quantifying and incorporating nonlinear and coupled feedbacks among human and natural systems this model also will inform efforts to assess the immediate and long term impacts of environmental and social shocks (e.g., climate change, drought, fisheries collapse, disease emergence, social unrest) on resource and livelihood sustainability.

In addition to bringing together a group of researchers who venture beyond disciplinary boundaries to build a new model of integration, this project will have direct and prolonged impacts on education, international collaboration, capacity building, health outcomes, poverty alleviation and sustainability. The project?s commitment to outreach, engagement and capacity building in Africa ensures that it will provide invaluable international experience to U.S.-based students and lifelong collaborations and associations for all individuals and institutions involved in the research effort. Project results and the framework created by this research will be of great practical value to agencies (e.g., USAID, FAO, WHO, UNEP, IUCN) and non-governmental organizations (e.g., WCS, CI, WWF, CARE, CRS) who can provide policy pathways for poverty alleviation, natural resource sustainability, economic development, biodiversity conservation, and the improvement of health outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to understand how the dynamics of wildlife populations (mammals and fish) affected the livelihoods and health of rural communities that rely on these resources for food and income. This may seem a narrow question at first glance, but in fact, wildlife is the dominant source of animal protein for more than 1.5 billion people. Furthermore, wildlife harvest on land and at sea is the single largest source of employment on Earth, accounting for at least 15% of all jobs. Thus, understanding how changes in the availability of these resources impacts our economies and health is of critical importance, particularly given steady increases in human consumption, market globalization, and environmental variability.

The research took place in 29 communities in Ghana, Kenya and Madagascar. The work at these sites involved: a) quantifying wildlife distribution and abundance, primarily using transect and camera trap surveys, but also harvest data; b) characterizing spatial and temporal patterns of wildlife harvest by communities; c) measuring the value of wildlife as a source of food and income to local communities; and d) quantifying the relationships between wildlife consumption and household wealth with measures of human health including nutrition, disease, and child development. Data collection for objectives b-d involved continuous study of more than 3000 households and 8000 individuals over the life of the project. Specifically, households and individuals were visited at regular intervals (weekly, monthly or quarterly) to measure wildlife harvest or purchase, daily diet, income, and health, including the growth and development of children.

Result of the study revealed great variability among wildlife populations subject to harvest, including declines of many populations critical to food and livelihoods, such as that of Nile perch in Kenya. The response within communities to declining wildlife availability or increased cost of wildlife was dramatic and varied. In some areas, communities engaged in risky livelihoods, such as prostitution, or turned to illegal practices, such as logging, mining or trafficking of ivory, in efforts to account for lost food or income. These efforts seldom filled the livelihood or food security gaps created by diminished wildlife resources. Furthermore, our results showed that lost access to wildlife had powerful negative impacts on human health. These impacts included increased rates of protein deficiency, stunted growth and cognitive development in children, and reduced quality of breast milk among nursing mothers. 

By studying the interactive dynamics of wildlife, livelihoods and health, we were able to identify unexpected pathways linking these central aspects of planetary health. For example, our results showed that individuals dealing with chronic illness were more likely to engage in environmentally-destructive harvest practices. These practices, in turn, reduced the long term capacity of ecosystems to sustain local food supply and economies. This finding showed a previously unrecognized connection between human health and our management of natural resources. Our findings also showed that the relationship between household wealth and wildlife consumption is not a simple linear trend. In some areas, particularly where rural regions have strong connections to urban markets, household wealth was positively correlated with wildlife consumption. However, in more isolated and economically marginalized areas, the poorest households showed the greatest use and reliance on wildlife.

In summary, this study examined the coupled dynamics of wildlife, livelihoods and human health in regions undergoing rapid demographic, economic and environmental change. The study's major results highlight pathways through which national and international efforts may help communities transition towards sustainability in the face of these changes. However, the results also show the far-reaching and profound impacts of declining wildlife resources on people and economies.
